title: wanhao duplicator i3 alternative spool mount.

description.text:
I just dont like the stock spool holder. even though its metal it is still weak..
i find it sagging as soon as i put on a roll of filament.
here is an alternative to the stock holder. (much stiffer)
also has a hole for a lockdown screw so once you slide it on the frame you can lock it in place with a M3-.5x 16mm or longer. socket cap screw.. (might want to put a piece of tape where the screw contacts . it can leave a circular scratch from the screw in the paint.)

in cura.
0.2mm layer height
2mm shell thickness
1mm top and bottom thickness
15% overlap infill
grid infill

I tried using a bit of FeastWatson Prooftint oak wood stain on it and the effect is quite good. I didnâ€™t expect the stain to go very well on the ABS but it comes out really nice

title: Duplicator i3 feet: Foam Remix
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a minor remix of the "ninjaflexV4" feet for the wanhao duplicator i3. I made the pocket shallower to better accept some foam I had laying around instead of printing a ninjaflex plug. I also made the screw slightly wider (2%) for better engagement with the mount.

The foam I used is approximately 9mm or 0.3inches thick. I put a drop of superglue to keep it in place but this probably wasn't necessary.

Printed with PLA @200C with 0.15mm layers. Currently I have 6 of them installed.

This customizable creation allows you to create a mold for any Lego brick size. Bring the fun of Legos to the beach!

This is my first OpenSCAD design! Hope you like it!

More pictures coming soon.

Update 7/12/15:
I included two sample molds for anyone to download.

Update 7/13/15:
I fixed the problem where Customizer timed out when creating large molds by optimizing the code to use 3D solids rather than 2D geometry.
Added the word "Lego" to each peg.
Added a scaling feature to the code.
Made the mold walls thinner to make it easier to print.

Print with the pegs towards the build plate with supports to get the best result.

Mine was printed on an Ultimaker2 in red PLA at 215C, .15 mm layer height, and support.

author: SonnyDR

title: Flag stop for Festool MFT rail

description.text:
This is a stop for the Festool MFT/3 rail guide.
It has a foldable steel bar so that multiple stops can be set up and used on the same rail.

The block is assembled with two M6x20 bolts, two M6 nuts and a washer.
The knob was designed with the great nut knob generator: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:713300, and thus requires that one of the bolts has an hex head.

It is preferrable to use a locknut (with a nylon insert) to secure the steel bar or it will get loose as you fold/unfold it.
Also, an additionnal nut can be added just under the knob. It will help releasing the block in case the underside nut does not go down by itself. This requires a longer M6x25 bolt.

I did not try to 3D print the steel stop as I thought it would be too flexible at the original thickness. Instead I cut it with a metal saw in an old shutter hinge. I also used files and sandpaper (and time and sweat) to get it to the final dimensions.

Printed in PLA at a Z resolution of 0.22mm and with a 25% infill.
Again, using nuclear green for the knob is highly recommended ;)

title: Di3 LCD Angler with E-Stop and SD Slot

description.text:
Making to easier to read, adds a 35º tilt the flat LCD faceplate of the version 1 Wanhao Duplicator i i3 and clones. Adds an emergency stop button without drilling that adds a small arm that pushes a button hidden by the faceplate. Optional slot for a Micro SD to SD extension. Reuses existing screws, and then attaches to base with one screw.

Warning:
If you mount your spool holder on the power supply box, use the use the Melzi highrise file. The screws are too long and will hit the board if you use the Melzi offset one. Thanks for the headsup Azza.

New set of files.

Di3 LCD angler SD-no vents.stl is without vents.
Di3 LCD angler SD-left.stl moved the SD slot on left side.
Di3 LCD angler 2b.stl is without SD slot.
Di3 LCD angler SD.stl has SD slot.
Di3 LCD Angler with SD set.stl is a full SD set with circuit board offsets and stop button.

Printed at .25mm layer height in PLA with supports. I used S3D with fast honeycomb at 15% fill, 3 shells and 3 layers. Removed all supports except for the little ones on the upper tab and the supports for the SD slot and recessed screw hole. Total print time for a set was about 4 hour. The faceplate mounting side should be face down on the bed. Make sure you clean out the supports well under the tabs.

  • Remove front 6 LCD faceplate screws. Remove the LCD connector.
  • Wiggle the face plate with the attached LCD over the stop button lever in first, then the angle the rest on. Not tight, jut a bit of finagling.
  • Replace all the screws in the faceplate except of the bottom one. Slowly tighten the screws so they tap the angler as you tighten them. May help to ream them out a bit with a 2.5 mm hex wrench.
  • reattach the cable.
  • put the new assembly over the opening and slide down.
  • check the bottom hole alignment, and then screw in the remaining screw.

For the SD set up
at your own risk. YMMV.
You need a MicroSD to SD extension. Mine had a case around the SD side. I was able to easily pop it off.
You also need a small strip of heavy duty double stick tape.

If you mount the spool holder on the power supply case, print two of the Melzi highrise parts. If you use the mounting holes for the spool holder on the top of printer, print two melzi offsets.

  • unplug the power cord.
  • unscrew remove the top of the case
  • with the base on it side and the top on its top, move the 4 screws and nylon washers mounting the circuit board
  • insert the micro SD extension
  • drop in the printed highrises or the offsets over the raised screw bosses
  • if using the offset ones, put the circuit board over the offsets making sure you hook it under the offset ends, and replace the 4 screws and nylon washers and tighten
  • on the highrise version, replace the 4 screws and use nylon washers on the top two, and tighten. Snap in the circuit board. Make sure it hooks in the the pins, at the bottom, then snap it down.
  • doublecheck the MicroSD extension is properly seated. Tape if necessary.

Make sure the SD slot is cleared out of support material and do a test fit of the SD card holder. See above if you haven't attached the faceplate. If a decent fit:

  • add a slim strip of double stick tape to back of the LCD circuit board (see pics)
  • remove the protective backing of the tape
  • insert the SD reader angling it in
  • check to see that it is fully seat insert an SD card and then then press down adhering to the tape

comments.text: Did I do this wrong?  None of the original screws reach the holed tabs on the inside, so the only thing holding the angler in place are the plastic tabs printed on the new part.  But if I lift up slightly the angler just falls out.  Was I supposed to purchase longer screws?  I mean it works nicely, but...

comments.text: The bottom screw is the only one holding the angler on--but it goes into the hole in the deep channel on the bottom.

Front panel is size of ~120*110. micro-sd slot is integrated on the board, so i cant use SD cards :/ these small TF cards are so small that its annoying, i allready lost one. Usually TF cards are used on devices to save space and or wheight, but why here on 10kg+ device?

comments.text: The e-stop is just a button that is hidden behind the metal front plate. You could drill a hole, but I made a button that you install and hinges on a piece filament. Flip the button up, and press it. It pushes an offset arm thru the bottom screw hole.

comments.text: Offsets needed only if you want to add a microsd extender internally.
comments.author: Thijs275

comments.text: Any suggestion on a good micro SD to full size SD adapter that i3 would recognize? Tried this -- http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B0085GGO92, but it does't work (impossible to mount the card). Tried different types of full size SD cards... No luck. Works in Windows PC no problem, of course.
comments.author: frontline

comments.text: It's finicky. Make sure the micro card end is seated properly. Often you have to repower the machine after insetting a card. The 2gb card it came with has been flaky for most folks.
comments.author: frontline

comments.text: Yeah, all of these adapters are pretty raw. I did play with it for a little bit before completely giving up, repowering the machine and all... There are some references in Google Groups that the micro SD slot in Wanhao is severely underpowered and some folks actually wire up additional 3.3V line to support a full size SD adapter. I guess I'll switch to printing over USB for now. Constant juggling of micro SD card is too much of a hassle.
comments.author: idig3d

comments.text: I'd just like to thank you for this absolutely brilliant design! I printed mine in black ABS (didn't have black PLA), and on the second attempt it came out really well. A very small delamination at one spot, but a small dab of epoxy on the inside should take care of it.
comments.author: mroek

comments.author: talktosanjay3

comments.text: I used an SD Card To Micro SD Card Extension cable I got from China. Micro SD male end with SD female end. I popped the black case off the female side. The one I got is a lot longer than needed--24 inches, but it seems to work okay. It works but is a bit touchy. Don't bump the SD card while printing.

comments.text: sounds like a hack.  And not really a necessary one since there is already a micro sd port

comments.text: Not necessary, but more convenient. I'm 6'7" and microSD cards are too fiddly for my bigger hands. Full-sized SD cards are much easier to use. But now I use a Raspberry Pi running Octoprint so I can print over wifi.

author: leboscalet

description.text: I cobbled up this simple mount to link the X and Y drag chains (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:915487) The scad file is included so you can adjust the coupling to suite your requirements.

The part is made in two sections, the mount which is joined to the holder via a single 20mm M3 nut and bolt. The mount attaches to the X-Axis motor mount by replacing the 2 short bolts with 25 mm ones.

I used nylock nuts on the mount to secure the drag chains, on the Y Axis I used a washer to spread the load since its only mounted on one side. (Why ? because the wires were already in the chain when I made the part)

Can customize a few things including

the point at which the air jets point measured as mm below the bottom surface. Default at 5mm bellow.

Number of jets

The size of the ring

Dimensions of Blower mouth

Can have 2 blowers mirrored

*updated to remove internal wall

*update to holes closer to one side be smaller than those further from the blower

comments.text: This looks like a really nice design. However, in blower_single.stl the walls for the duct to the air chamber are extending into the air chamber, which would seem to inhibit the flow of air to all but the closest jets. In the scad file, it is setup for a fan that is perpendicular to the circular portion of the duct, but I need to rotate it such that the fan is tangent (i.e. rotate the fan 90 degrees).

author: traxsboy

description.text:
This boat is one of three of the models using a rubber band that I created after a few tries and I tried to put weight on it by using coins and weighing approximately 32.77 grams (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fsYgb2xobzQ).

Website address of this model comes from this address: http://blog-imgs-49.fc2.com/b/o/a/boat328/Boat-Blue-Prints-3.jpg, then I cut it a little so that the flat part and can be printed, the middle there are 2 pieces of support that can be broken also to reduce the weight of the boat, and the inside of the boat is made does not fit contours and has a 50-degree angle.

Beside this model there is a pipe with a thickness of 0.5 mm so useful when printing "boat engine" is not twisted.

The concept of this boat using a model boat with outboard engine, after I saw some pictures on the internet if the propellers how under the hull and slightly backward.

Without coins: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dP6Yn2Cyz8U&feature=youtu.be

https://vydesyl.wordpress.com/2012/08/30/boat-building-with-wooden-boat-blueprints/

1. Print boat.stl with layer-height 0.2 mm and boat-propeller.stl with 0.1 mm, also add brim 2 mm, infill 100%, skirt for boat-propeller.stl is 50 layers.
  2. Cut brim with scissors, as well as two pieces of support is to break it.
  3. Drill a hole in the propeller using pcb drill diameter 0.8 mm.
  4. Sandpaper all surfaces that come in contact as shown in photo 2 marked red line, which is in between the propeller and the retaining surface, and the surface of the backing with a rubber band hooks, sandpaper that is in use is the first number to 80, then 320 and finally by 1000.
  5. Straighten a paper clip and cut into 3 cm long, bend it round about 5 mm with a width of approximately 1.5 mm, and insert it into the hole propeller continued into the bracket.
  6. Create the arch to tie a rubber band by using pliers with the help of a nut or bolt diameter of 4 mm.
  7. Insert rubber bands into a slit hole that's been made to the hook on the front of the boat.
  8. Rubber bracelet that I use is approximately 45 mm in diameter or if it is associated not too tight.
  9. Turn the propeller counter-clockwise, and then insert it into the water.

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

title: Z braces for Wanhao Duplicator i3, Cocoon Create, Maker Select, and Malyan M150 i3 3D printers.
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This kit will add rigidity to your printer, giving you better prints more often.

Does it work and is it worth doing?
Just see maker zsonybrasco's before & after shots:
http://www.thingiverse.com/make:198927

Here is a good, and short, article on 3D printer rigidity:
http://dabbletron.com/why-is-rigidity-important-for-3d-printers/

To compliment this mod, have a look at my Z Extensions:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1444979
(For an additional 37mm of Z clearance)

BTW...
This design was powered by beer... just like lots of hobbies... so if you like this design and you'd like to buy me one... or two...
https://www.paypal.me/azza68
A huge THANKS and CHEERS to those who've already shouted.

This design uses two 8mm or 5/16" threaded rods. The rods lock at the bottom and have adjustment at the top. These rods brace the Z axis towers, to the front of the Y axis, keeping them vertical and square to the build plate.

There are also two braces for the Y-axis, front and rear. These enable the Y belt to be tensioned correctly by stopping the Y motor torque from pulling the frame ends together.

No need to drill any new holes in the printer, but you do need to replace some short 3mm screws for longer ones (10mm). The short screws are reused for the Y braces.

See "Instructions" below for further detail.

Our friends over at "3D Printer Wiki" have also put together a build guide for this mod:
http://3dprinterwiki.info/wiki/wanhao-duplicator-i3/duplicator-i3-basic-mods/z-brace/
If you get a redirect: try going to http://3dprinterwiki.info/ and clicking through to the required page... and do check out all the other great tips they have for the i3.

Enjoy.

Let us know what you think.

Any feedback is welcome, within reason ;-)

EDIT: the instructions got mashed in a recent website change, sorry for this, I'm working at getting things ordered for the new format. It might take some time though. Please take the time to investigate the new layout and check the images (there's 81 of them!). Cruise the comments section for anything still lost to you... as a last resort, feel free to ask. Thank goodness for Internet Archive.org is all I can say!

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm or 0.15mm (much slower)

Infill:

50% (hexagonal, if able, better but slower)

Notes:

1mm to 1.2mm walls or 3 shells.

All files have been inspected in Simplify3D. All files should now be manifold and compliant to your slicer. Tested in Cura & S3D.

PLA or ABS, or your choice of plastic.
They're rock solid in PLA!
Sufficiently over-engineered, shall we say.
I do not recommend ABS (not for any hobby grade 3D printer) but it will work if it doesn't warp too much.

PLA gives a very strong print and works best on the Di3.
Avoid transparent/glassy colours; they tend to be brittle.
Solid coloured PLA filaments usually make better mechanical/structural parts.

No supports required.

No rafts required.

Parts required to buy:
(NOTE: if you have a Plus model printer with a touch screen, you will need longer rods, please measure before cutting.)
2 x 400-410mm lengths of 8mm or 5/16" threaded rod.
4 x 8mm or 5/16" nuts;
2 x 8mm or 5/16" Nylocs (lock nuts or locked nuts, or glue may be used).
20 x M3 x 10mm (or longer **** if you cannot find 10mm).
4x Rubber feet (whatever you've got that fit, self adhesive or glue-on).
1x 4.8mm wide cable tie or zip-tie (or similar size).
1x M5 x 20mm machine head screw (only if your front Y belt idler has a domed head).

Optional:
If you wish to make the Y belt idler even more rigid, use a M5 x 30mm and an extra Nyloc nut and a washer or two. (See pictures and search comments for "M5" for more detail.)

**** If you use M3 bolts longer than 10mm, check your clearances; some machines might have issues on the top mounts when the X beam goes near to full height. Be warned!

Assembly?
Obvious for some but there can be a few hurdles.
Please look at all of the pictures if you don't want to read the whole page; there's 80+ to look at, and they all say it better than I can type it. ;-)

Warning!!!
Your printer may be bent or off-square and you do not realise it.

Before putting any strain on the rods, release the tension on the four screws that secure the Z-towers to the Y-axis. Failure to do this may result in distortion of your printer!

If there is not enough range of movement, to make the Z-Y axis square, remove each of the rear Z-tower to Y-axis screws. (One screw per tower is enough with this mod.)

Before fitting:
Raise the nozzle about 25mm or 1" off the print bed; to avoid the nozzle bottoming out. (Some people have reported this occurring due the Z tower pivoting when being squared.) You may need to adjust/move your Z limit switch to compensate in more extreme cases.

If you are having trouble inserting the rod:
Move the printer so that the front feet are over the edge of your table/bench. That way the rod can be dropped lower than the level of the table, and easily lifted up through the hole in the top bracket.
If you find your rod does not align to both holes, in the foot to the top bracket, your printer is bent! (Mine was too, "hello sailor", welcome to the club.)

If your printer is bent:
There are two large hex-headed machine screws holding each Z-tower in place. Release the tension on both screws until you have enough movement in the Z-axis to insert the rods. If there is not enough movement with both loose screws, then you need to remove one screw from each tower (I removed the rear most screw, but it doesn't matter which just do the same on both towers). YOUR Z TOWER CAN NOW FALL OVER... DO NOT DROP IT!

The front Y brace uses a 4.8mm wide cable tie to tension the belt idler bolt. (You may recycle the 3mm by 5mm screws, left over from the Z brace mod, as these will fit the front & rear Y braces).
(The latest printers from the factory have domed nuts on the front Y idler, so there's nowhere for the zip-tie to grip. You can either replace the screw with a M5 x 20, of just not use a zip-tie. The brace should hold on OK without the zip-tie if you re-use the short M3 screws.)

With the printer now supported at all four corners there is none of the rocking that most early owners were reporting.

There is no need for more than 4 feet; the printer will be very stable and easier to level with only four. If you feel the need for more feet, please feel free to morph into a centipede or just visit the Remix section of this page.

Gluing rubber pads under the feet assists greatly in isolating noise from the printer being amplified by your desktop/table. Self adhesive rubber feet are available at hardware stores and supermarkets. These will make your printer much quieter!

Further reading, should you wish...

Use brims if you're printing the "BottomxxxxxForOneNut.stl" parts; as the small "nut plug" does not have a lot of surface area on the print bed. (5 brims worked OK for me.)

Bases/feet print as they would stand/mount when finished, and might require a little support but only touching the build plate... they probably don't really need that.

Back legs print flat, no support needed.

Choose "balls" or "balls mk2", your choice, smooth or grippy.
Just print the balls as they appear in the preview, with support disabled, and near enough to full infill.

The round plug, in the middle of the ball, is for support and it will pull out cleanly with needle nose pliers; so you do not need to enable support in your slicer for the balls.

Options:

Printed parts:

all versions-
‘TopLeft.stl’
‘TopRight.stl’
2x Balls.stl or 2x ballsMk2.stl (your choice)
There's two choices of front feet:
( 1.)
-if using two nuts on each front foot (this requires two more 8mm or 5/16" nuts)
‘BottomRightForBalls.stl’
‘BottomLeftForBalls.stl’
(also found on "Plate2.stl")
1x Balls.stl or 1x ballsMk2.stl (your choice)
( 2.)

for one Nyloc nut and a glued plug on each foot-
BottomRightForOneNut.stl
BottomLeftForOneNut.stl
(also found on "Plate1.stl")
There's two choices of back feet:
( 1.) (also found on "Platex.stl" files)
BackFootxxxx.2.2.stl very sturdy and have big bases for bugger rubber pads, and
(2.)
Foot_Rear_xxxxx.stl which are quicker to print but don't have much bottom are to stick rubber pads onto.

There are two files for the Back Y Braces:
"Back_Y_Brace.4.stl" is for most people and "Back_Y_Brace.5.stl" is for people contemplating the use of a cable chain on the Y-axis (it has the fairly obvious extra bit/horn with all the holes). Cable chain should be 7mm x 7mm ID, which is the same generic chain used elsewhere on the Di3. You can buy it on eBay etc. (Like the Front Y-axis brace, this new brace also uses the short M3 screws left over from the other parts.)

I've printed the one for the chain, which is directly based on the other, and it works well.
Far more rigidity on the back frame plate now; I have a resilient motor mount fitted and it flexes before anything else does. Without bracing there was flexing at the point where the cables go through the back frame.

All the above choices work equally well, it's a matter of aesthetics and personal choice.

Background:

My first Di3 was one of the first batch shipped and it suffered a mild flogging as a result of the first generation of packaging not being of the best design. I now also have a V2.1 at home and another V2.1 at work, they all have this mod done (amongst other mods).

Try as I might, I was not able to adjust the Z axis to be square; there simply was not enough adjustment available from the OEM fasteners . An otherwise great printer was less than perfect. Design time...

The design files may be edited with the free 3D design software from RS, DesignSpark Mechanical. You can get it from Radio Spares website "rs-components dot com", just look for the "DesignSpark" link on your local distributors front page. http://www.rs-online.com/designspark/electronics/eng/page/mechanical

You may assemble this mod using any combination of the parts, as you see fit, this is the version used on my 3 Di3's and is what's shown in the pictures above.

1x ‘TopRight.stl’
1x ‘TopLeft.stl’
2x Balls.stl
2x ballsMk2.stl
1x BottomRightForOneNut.stl
1x BottomLeftForOneNut.stl
1x BackFootRight.2.2.stl
1x BackFootLeft.2.2.stl
1x Back_Y_Brace.5.stl
1x Front_Y_Brace.3.stl
(You may use other variations, this is just my recommendation.)
Got a Malyan M150 i3 3D printer? Use these http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1509637
Got a WanHao Di3 Plus? Use these http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1653631

Spare NutPlug files have been uploaded, just in case someone needs them; being small parts these can sometimes come loose from the printbed. If yours print OK, then ignore these files.

description.header: Nuts: how many and what for?
description.text:
M8 or 5/16" nuts...

As few as 6 nuts, or as many as 8, depending on which front foot design you choose.

 The recommended version uses 2 Nylocs and 4 normal nuts.
 The variant uses 2 Nylocs and 6 normal nuts.

Ideally at least 1 nut on each rod should be a Nyloc.
I suggest one Nyloc nut inside each front foot.

If you don't have at least one Nyloc, then Loctite or glue the bottom most nut into the front foot; because you need something to stop the threaded rod from turning, or ever vibrating loose.

Don't use Nyloc nuts in the nut balls.
Unless you have very clean, high quality, threaded rods: I suggest using 4 normal nuts on the top brackets. It will be much easier to adjust when squaring the printer. The friction of plastic-on-plastic will hold the nuts & balls in place nice an securely... and we all like our nuts & balls held just thus.

Note: it is recommended to do this before fitting the rubber feet under the printer.

To get a good square print you must make the frame square.
Placing the printer on the flat surface and squaring the tower (Z axis) to the surface is a good start and better than OEM.

Get yourself a large engineers/carpenters square.
Any tools store or hardware store should have them or you can steal your fathers (he wont miss it immediately).

Place the printer on a smooth flat surface (Mums dining table is usually the best; she had dad pay a fortune for it.)

Ensure the bottom of the rods are fixed tightly into the front feet, ideally using Nyloc nuts. If you've made the variant option now is the time to tighten the nut ball on the bottom feet.

Adjust the nut balls on the top brackets to square the printer to the tabletop/bench-top.
It might be difficult to find a straight edge on the printer Z-tower to use your square against; I used the front edge closest to the outermost corner, or bend. (If you're using mums furniture, be careful not to scratch it unless you have younger/weaker siblings.)

Once everything is square, tighten the balls. Then recheck for square. Rinse and repeat.
Repeat until satisfied. Your printer should now be able to travel back to its normal place of rest without coming out of square. (Scatter some of your smaller siblings toys to cover any "tracks" you might have left.)

Checking:
Now home the axis and level the print-bed.
Print something with long square edges in the Y and Z planes, and check the finished print against your square (your new one or dads old one, if he hasn't missed it yet).

For the OCD:
To get the best, absolute, square print you must square the actual axis to each other.

comments.text: A tip if you're installing the Z Brace mod: The Thingiverse page says to use 10mm long screws while http://3dprinterwiki.info/wiki/wanhao-duplicator-i3 says 20mm. Stick with 10mm. Last night I heard a terrible sound as I was going to bed. It turns out that the 16mm screws I used stuck out so much that the X axis was hitting them and the Z screws were turning and skipping. Fortunately it happened before I fell asleep and I was able to stop it without any serious damage.
comments.author: A_Str8

comments.text: Good call... I'll put a note in the page, to check clearances no matter which length is used...with changes in production there will be those that hit and those that miss.
comments.author: A_Str8

The Y braces usually go on so tight that they won't ever fall off, and the screws are just for reassurance. :)

comments.text: Which mods did you end up using?  new MS owner, have seen several of the recommended mods/upgrades lists, almost done printing my zbrace.  just curious which specific mods helped the most.
comments.author: NeuroX33

comments.text:
Diii3 cooler and a good blower fan.
Full metal Micro Swiss hot end and coated nozzle.
Hand match the bearings for perfect fit.
Swap the idlers for toothed bearing idlers.
Blueprint the whole printer to get everything square and running just right.
Don't screw with that which you do not know though; else it might not work as good or at all.

comments.text: Hi guys, I'm having a problem and hope someone can help.
comments.author: Kolasinski

comments.text: This just happened to me. The problem I had was Cura had a larger default filament diameter than I had, and I did't double check all of my settings... That threw off it's calculations about how much material would be getting extruded and resulted in the brittle design. It reminded me of a piece of pumice (albeit printed in PLA).
comments.author: Kolasinski

comments.text: Can you post a picture of the print?
comments.author: Kolasinski

comments.text: My experience suggests your PLA is not of the best quality; for structural parts the colour should be solid (no sign of it being clear), as this indicates that filler has been used in the formulation. Filler in PLA makes it more plastic, less brittle, and generally it will print consistently for environmental changes. It will generally cost a bit more for quality, but your work will be easier.
comments.author: Kolasinski

comments.text: I have everything printed and installed. What's the best method to level the tower part to 90 degrees from the bed?  a framing square from the desktop looks way off so I'm leery to try and move it that much.

comments.text: I used a large engineers/carpenters square and aligned the bench-top and the outside front edge of the Z towers (the folded edge). This works well. title: Elder Sign Nightlight
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Terrified of the cosmic horrors lurking in the shadowy recesses of your bedroom, bunkhouse, or boudoir? Does the prospect of falling prey to Lovecraftian monstrosities in the dead of night sound unappealing to you? Do your brain-stuffs swell to the point of bursting trying to comprehend the unfathomable evil that besieges the material realm from the stygian void beyond time and space? Well worry no more, because the Elder Sign Nightlight is here to give you the sweet, sanity replenishing sleep you've been needing since you first opened the tome of unspeakable secrets you purchased at that Marrakesh trading post!

Emblazoned with the iconic protective sigil that keeps the Old Ones at bay, this 3D printable talisman is sized to fit a Night Ize Spotlit LED keychain (just remove the LED from the keychain portion), though any small light should work. Print the two parts in translucent filament and they'll fit together without need of glue, allowing easy access to the light when it comes time to change the battery.

Enjoy!

DISCLAIMER: Failing to print with ideal specifications may lead to WRONG ANGLES.
Printed mine at a .2 layer height with 10% infill in black, translucent ABS from Hatchbox.

This little block provides mounts for a 3-pin Molex fan connector and banana jacks as output connectors while having a space for a female 5.5x2.1mm DC jack as an input. This allows for using common AC-to-DC transformers to power and test devices that don't have a barrel-jack style connector.

The top houses the two outputs while the inside of the box holds the female input jack. The lid is secured with four small screws.

(be specific) clamp_ and dry_ are more likely to work than tiny_. Maybe a tip if it doesnt work, destroy the connection mechanism and heat a metal wire through both parts(with correct axis), and twist those together.

Clamps inspired on thingiverse user KidCrazy's 'KCS' clamp. Untested. Intended improvements are:
  • Made it parametric.
  • Guides to center it.
  • Holes to glue some filament on in order to hold a regular spring instead of a plastic one.
  • (optional, parametric)Gap behind the teeth improves hold pn clothing.

Many;
  • Springs are not properly parametric(actually left out the dry_spring.stl because it didnt work well)
  • Assembly could be easier. (That might mean just turning the guides off)
  • Parameters based on what the user want, and that dont require fiddling to get right.
  • When the distance between the prongs is small relative to the length the handles collide, increasing their distance would help.
  • More defaults.

Many;
  • Springs are not properly parametric(actually left out the dry_spring.stl` because it didnt work well)
  • Assembly could be easier. (That might mean just turning the guides off)
  • Parameters based on what the user want, and that dont require fiddling to get right.
  • When the distance between the prongs is small relative to the length the handles collide, increasing their distance would help.
  • More defaults.
As usual development versions on github, also released on fabfabbers.

Print it, the _set.stl files contains a pair with the plastic spring, _pair.stl without. Then put the parts together, it will resist a bit halfway due to the guide. Going in diagnonally seems to work better. If you use the plastic spring, just put it in. For regular springs there are probably multiple good strategies.

  • use metal wires and twisting them up, the spring then goes over the metal wires.

  • fuse bits of filament with the hot end, this was my initial plan
    but it didnt work well for me.

  • You could probably also just tie it with wire but i am not so sure how well that works.

  • Risk using nothing. Spring has friction with the plastic. There are also cones where the spring can go.

Printool is designed for fast and simple opening of a variety of screws and nuts.
The steel nails provide structural strength and ease of grip.

All you need is:
Download the suitable file
3D print it
Insert steel nails #10, #5, or #3 based on the chosen file
Screw/unscrew your project!

6 mm- #3 nails
12 mm-#5 nails
24 mm-#10 nails

author: Yubo

title: Heavy Duty Bottleholder for Twingo II

description.text:
I try to drink a lot. But the bottle holders in my car are to small for 1 litre bottels. So i designed my own one.
First part is bottle container. It has no holes, so if your bottle leaks or condensates your car will stay clean.
(I guess that you can reuse this for own design, too)
The second part is a hook that fits in the middle console.It is a little bit to wide in the middle, but i didn´t care about the looking. You can reduce the width if you like. The third part i designed as an alternative that must be prepared with 'hook tape' to be attatched at the side carpet.

author: esra

description.text:
A small trash can for the Velleman Vertex K8400 3D printer. It fits the triangular hole in the bottom panel of the printer.

Just scrape your scrap plastic in the trash instead of having it lying around at the bottom of your printer!

There are two sizes:
5cm deep (55 mm total height)
2.5 cm deep (30 mm total height)

OBS! it's a close fit
Print with support.

title: Tie Hanger
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A simple device to hang your neckties, because no matter how hard you try we all need to wear one from time to time.  Similar products in stores are no longer worth the price when we have the means to print our own!  
Designed to fit any standard closet rod.  There is 1.2 cubic inches of volume, costing around $0.2x in material
Please let me know if you experience any problems.

The overall length of the hanger is 97mm, so you might want to make sure the build platform is centered before printing.
Enjoy.

author: Starno

description.text:
Quick and dirty heatsinks.
Superglue copper mig welding tips to the driver chips.

comments.text: i like that idea,
comments.author: dissidence

comments.text: Or just buy SMD heatsinks which are probably cheaper than MIG Tips :p
comments.author: PhillyDee

comments.text: Does superglue work just as well as those expensive thermal adhesives from the electronics store?  (admitting my ignorance)
comments.author: MtDon

comments.text: In practice I think the Superglue works perfectly (at least for this design). The least I can say is that the heat is well transfered from the chip to copper tips because they become very hot, so using a thermal adhesive would probably not improve function noticeably.
comments.author: MtDon

comments.text: Thermal adhesives work better because they have higher thermal conductivity. In this situation, superglue may work well enough, but in a bad situation (such as a thick layer of glue between your chip and your sink), you could have much higher temperatures with the heat sink than without.
comments.author: CloudMaker

description.text: 15 cm high. Standard bucket. Work with most filaments.
Everything needed to make your very own Robo Beast instructions located at http://community.robo3d.com/index.php?threads/the-makings-of-a-beast.6141/#post-51151

comments.text: i can't believe everyone hasn't done this mod.  I want to order 700mm lead screws and 30 inch smooth rods. do you think a nema 17 can turn a 700mm length?  Did your extended build affect your printers performance?
comments.author: xLORDxSIDIUSx

comments.text: There are a few people that use the same lengths that you are using with no problems at all with the stock motors. And I have not noticed no preform ancestors decrease at all from the robo beast mod.
comments.author: xLORDxSIDIUSx

comments.text: Hmm.. I guess not many people are willing to take this mod on. I on the other hand accept the challenge! I've printed everything but I'm a little stumped how you are connecting the cable chain to the extruder and to the X axis assembly. I currently have cable chain on mine but it mounts to the other side where the extruder motor is and the other end attaches to the wall of the printer case. I like the idea that the whole chain would move up with the Z axis so I'd like to do it the same way you did. Can you point me in the direction where you got your version of the cable chain idea?
comments.author: claytonc2001

comments.text: There should be a .stl named cable chain end in my files. U mount the end of the cable chain to it like u did it to the side of the case. And you mount the cable chain end in front of the stepper motor that moves your X carriage. There is a pre-made hole on the base that the stepper motor sits on that you can attach the cable chain end to. I have  pictures on the robo3d forum linked in the details
comments.author: claytonc2001

comments.text:
Ok I see now. I'll probably do it a little different since I already have a chain in place.
Now I am really having a tough time figuring out what I should change the Z axis steps to in the configuration.h file. Currently mine are set to [code]#define DEFAULT_AXIS_STEPS_PER_UNIT {80,80,800,723.38} // default steps per unit for RoBo 3D R1[/code]
Can I ask what you changed yours to? I'm using 4 start acme lead screws with a 2mm pitch. I think it said that was 8mm per rotation? Not sure how that converts so I'm hoping you can help me with this.
comments.author: dbefore

comments.text: I think that's right.... you should look at the robo3d forums. There is a Thread there that explains what needs to be changed for the lead screw upgrade.
comments.author: claytonc2001

comments.text: It ended up being 400 but it was strange. I changed it I'm marlin and flashed the firmware. But it wouldn't recognize the new settings. I did it with a wide variation to make sure it wasn't changing and it wasn't. I ended up having to go into matter control and setting it in the eprom settings there. I don't get it but it's working now. I've ordered solid couplings but actually so far I'm pretty happy with the results even trgough I'm using the flexible couplings.
comments.author: dbefore

description.text:
TL;DR:

A removable bowden clamp for the Ultimaker 1's printing head.

This is a by-product of a detachable direct extruder for weak filaments.

Features:

  • provides additional hold on the printing head's tube
  • quick and non-destructive removal of bowden for "cold pulls"
  • (almost) no disassembly required
  • tube length cutting help tool included
  • it just works :-P

Although I created this for the original, old UM1 printing head, it should work (tm) for the newer editions, those that come with a black plastic part and the tube fitting on the top, too.

PRINTING:

All parts are already in their printing position.

I recommend a layer height of 0.1mm and an infill of 50%, or more.

The fixture plate (file "BowdenClamp_Fixture_Vnn.stl") requires support structures under the three corners.
It is not recommended to add support inside the slots for the nuts!

ASSEMBLY:

Steps (image numbers in order of appearance):

  • remove the fan
  • fix the lower aluminium plate with clamps (see img 2)
  • remove the four long printing head screws
  • unplug/unscrew the cables from the amplifier board
  • carefully lift the top wooden plate (see img 3)
  • unscrew as many amplifier board screws as neccessary to rotate or move it out of the way (::1::)
  • attach the tube cutting help tool (see img 4/5)
  • fix it with three of the four long screws (see img 6)
  • carefully cut the bowden with a sharp knife (again img 7)
  • remove the cutting help tool
  • put two 3mm nuts in the fixture plate
  • mount the fixture plate (see img 9)
  • roughen the end of the tube with abrasive paper
  • stick the tube into the hole of the bigger clamp part (see img 8)
  • loosely mount the smaller clamp part with four screws and nuts
  • align the angle of the clamp to avoid twisting the tube
  • tighten the screws (with sense, not force :-)
  • mount the clamp to the fixture plate

(::1::)
You don't need to drill new holes.
Even if it's sufficient to only use one screw and rotate the board a little, there's always at least one position in which the second screw can be put though the big 8mm holes.
A washer might be required in some cases.

DIY

In case you want to attach other clamps (or extruders ;-):
The distance of the mounting holes is 18mm.

BOM:

  • 4 printed parts
  • 6 x screw, (3x8)mm
  • 6 x nut 3mm

Because of my cats i don´t want to use really candles. So i bought electricle ones, but they are urgly... so i designed some covers that diffuse the light. I used natural ABS and no supports to print it.

author: Hommmer

description.text:
The Z-Axis bottom sensor on the Fabrikator is too low to be useful (it hits the bottom bracket before triggering the sensor).

This little part can be used in place of the existing sensor mount to put it high enough,

Caveat: This is untested as it turns out my bottom sensor is duff :-(

This cap protects your cold drinks in your 1 liter "Maßkrug" from flying insects or other dirt. There is one totally closed version and one with a 1cm hole for a straw (in case you enjoy non-beer drinks ;-) ).
Both have a small handle on top to take it off the stein.
Added version 2 for keeping the position on the stein better.

Yet another fully printed bottle opener.
The shape follows the curve of the crown cap to give the soft plastics optimum grip to be able to open the bottle.
I'm not sure how many bottles it can open until the edge wears off, but so far my printed one opened quite some. Sure ones with metallic inlay (e.g. coins) last longer.

Just for fun =)
I think u need to use a condom, coz all plastic things r porous, or print it as prototype to make such from metal by casting for example.

In original its 10 cm long (about 8 cm of working part) and 3.5 cm in diameter.

description.text: This is a simple belt holder. Very simple design and prints well without a raft on my heated build platform.
Helping a friend to have her photophore lasercutted at the gsi-lab :)

Earth No Sea Relief Globe is a smaller version of thing:86681, Earth Relief Globe. It is a match for thing:91468, Earth Sea Relief Globe, and is meant to be quickly and easily printed. It was created from a version of Scripps copyright data set, SRTM30_PLUS V8.0. See srtm30plus_copyright.txt for the license. DJ Moews's program "Globe" was used. The program and the data are available at http://djm.cc/dmoews.html Input to globe was: --map altitude data/srmt30plus 5400 2700 sbigendiandibyte --gridpoints 256 --map-scale 60 >earth_no_sea.stl. Earth_no_sea.stl was centered and scaled by 0.0000075 to yield a globe about 3.5 inches in diameter. Two stl files are available: earth_no_sea.stl and
earth_no_sea_base.stl - the same globe with a base added at the south pole

On my Replicator I used two shells and 2% infill and printed earth_no_sea_base.stl directly on the build platform. Print time was a little over 5 hours. Earth_no_sea.stl was printed with a raft and external support and took a little under 7 hours to print. See the closeup view of the northwestern Pacific in the image shown above. The beginning of the Hawaiian archipelago is marked. A USGS picture of the northern Pacific at http://pubs.usgs.gov/gip/dynamic/Hawaiian.html shows a similar view.

title: Pursa I3 8mm. Y-Axis Pulley Assembly A Much Needed Improvement.

description.text:
Have you noticed on the Y-Axis the drive belt rides to the left or the right if that little U joint is not in just the right position. Well I have and I am not going to take it any more. I mean what were the designers thinking of when they came up with that idea? I have fix that with totally adjustable Y-Axis Assembly .The photos are of the model just before the last improved updated version. i could not print it at the time of this release due to a clogged head / nozzle. But I promise you that as soon as that is resolved I will print this version and update with pictures. Well here are the pictures of the new improved Y-Axis assembly, they are in blue. File #3 no need for washers between the bearings and wall.

Created with Design Spark Mechanical, a FREE and extremity easy to learn and use CAD http://www.rs-online.com/designspark/electronics/eng/page/mechanical

Have a great day. :-)

printed:

This cooling system is based on ideas drawn on this site.
This cooling system is adapted to the Chinese PrusA i3 assembly.
This cooling system uses a standard fan 40 * 40 mm, and allows you to create two streams for blowing the extruder and the printable area of one fan. You can set the printable area illumination with LED ring diameter of 60 mm.

I got some sheets of sandpaper 230mmx280mm (a little wider and shorter than A4) and wanted a handy holder to turn strips of it into sanding blocks to make jobs easier. This is what I came up with.
It is designed to grip sheets of sandpaper cut to 40mm wide by just over 200mm long, but with the files included it should be easy to re-design to your needs.

Print off a part and fit the hole with one M4 bolt, two washers and a wing nut.
Slice your sandpaper into appropriately-sized strips from the back and do any tearing necessary.
Wrap a slice of sandpaper around the holder and tuck the ends into the gap, then tighten up the wing nut while holding the bolt fixed.
Sand away!

author: Yubo

title: Action Cam LED Lamp and Torch

description.text:
Good morning everyone!
Here i will show you my project. I am really proud of it, I love the idea of sharing it with you, and i hope you will enjoy it!
My aim was not to create something just usefull or just nice to watch, but something that can have both these two characteristics. So i realized this object.
This is a little box with a switch on the top and a power led on the frontal side. Basically the main idea is a Torch. I designed the style of an Action Cam because : n1 i love the essential design. n2 so the ''torch'' is really small ,compact, and strong (great skills!). After this first step i decided to create a way to let it stick quite everywhere. Fortunately the way already exists and is really easy. I love ball-joints! So I realized 4 balls on the two big sides of this box. Using ball joints i created some legs for the action cam, so it can stand everywhere .In my opinion, anyway, it was not still enough so i realized a chain of ball joints using the project you can find here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:584405 . There you can find the best and smallest ball joints I have ever printed. I also designed a ball joint with two balls and one with two holes, it can be really useful! Using these things you can stick the Action Cam essentially everywhere ( look the photos where I put them on the bike! it worked perfectly PS there I used http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5170 because i was still printing the one i realized, it works as well!). Then it was an object really useful, but not really nice, so i decided to play with leds. I created some covers (they are not custumizable on Custumizer because i am not good with OpenScad, but if you would like to customize them, please just ask me, i will create and upload them as quickly as i can ), i personally used the wu tang logo because I am a fan :D There are three different kinds, two of them opened and one closed, check the results watching photos, the effect is wonderful!
So you can use it ;
as an accesory, it is really useful if this summer you are planning to do a nice excursion in a dark place.
as a lamp, is really nice.
as a torch, for exemble on your bike or somewhere else.
and in houndreds different ways!
Let' s find your way and show me your amazing results!
I hope you will enjoy yourself using it as i enjoyed myself realizing it

N1 the most important thing! Is not possible to open Cases in Customizer because i don' work with OpenScad. But!!!! If you want to customize your cases, please send me the logo or the write you would like on the case and i will create and upload the project as soon as I can! ( i work with Rhino, this operion is really easy and fast on that program, so don' t worry, you will not wait ages for a case.)

Now how I made it:
I realized the circuit ( you can see it in the picture) using 12 V leds (the common light for the car) that is really powerful. You can connect it to a 12 V battery or to 8 button batteries of 1,5 V each one. (The size is really similar.). So i bought this stuff and a classic switch, i paid 3 euros. I scaled the back and the frontal part of the Cam on 105% so the circuit fit better. As you can see in the picture i put all the circuit in the box and i closed it.At this point there are two important thngs. Number one: it is better if you use some tape to stick the wires because if they go out from the place where they should be, there will be a gap between the two parts of the box (like in mine :/) but it is not a problem at all. Number two: use some scissors to modify the holes and the connection between the two parts, it will fit better.
So now your circuit is in the camera and the camera is closed! You can put the Led in his place and start to enjoy.
Cases have to be scaled 105%.
I used 30% infill, no supports (but probably is better to use them in a couple of places) 200 microns and raft for the cases. (If you use Kapton the result should be better).
It is all really easy and fast to print!

author: Rivinski

description.text:
This light mounts on a MK7 extruder such as the one on a Folger 2020. You use the light holder and one of the clips. The holder has holes for three white LEDs (approx 3V each), and you should connect these up in series, with a 220 ohm resistor. The whole thing can then be connected to a 12V power supply. There are two clips. Both attach to a small piece of the screw holding the fan one exposed at the bottom of the heat sink. One clip goes straight down, the other sticks out a bit and then points the light back in at an angle. The pieces fit together a bit loosely. I use a small shim of rubber where the clip attached to the fan screw and where the clip and holder attach, and these seem to give enough friction.

The angled clip could be improved by moving the light a bit further in. Currently the brightest spot is to the right of where the nozzle is.

author: bobson_h

description.text:
The area between y=x and y=x^2 is rotated about the line y=1.25. This creates a volume of revolution which looks a bit like a bowl, but with a conical interior and a big hole in the bottom.

This model pairs with Strange Bowl: 16 washers & 16 shells (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:897934 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:897936).

This model was designed and printed by my WLU summer research student Emily Jaekle ('16).

We knew that printing this on the MakerBot would not be successful due to the number of supports. Instead we printed it on the FormLabs Form 1+ printer.

We used the grey color, and adjusted the suggested rotation of the object to minimize supports in the interior. (We ended up deleting some of them.) The printer claimed there were some problems with the design, however it seemed to print OK.

Update: we have also printed this shape on the ProJet 260 powder printer. It is colored red on the inside and blue on the outside. Thanks to Dave Pfaff for his help with this.

description.text:
I created this to find into my Prius cup holder so that my phone would fit in it sitting upright. I have a OnePlus One with a thin case and it fits just snug enough to keep it from falling out when going around corners.

As a nice side thing, this will actually fit some small drinks in the middle so you don't have to remove it if you need the cup holder.

title: Hyperboloid of one sheet - with forumla

description.text:
This model shows the hyperboloid of one sheet: x^2+y^2-z^2=1. The equation is imprinted in the surface. There is a second .stl file showing the surface without the equation.

This model was designed and printed by my WLU summer research student Emily Jaekle ('16). For more information see http://mathvis.academic.wlu.edu/2015/07/16/quadratic-surfaces-hyperboloid-of-one-sheet/.

This object was made on a MakerBot2X. We used the following settings:
2 shells
0.20mm layer height
10% infill (hexagonal pattern)
No supports
Raft off

There are times when you'd like to make a connection which is linked to another attachment using the least distance possible. This will work great. I could not find the exact thing I needed, so I made it myself. If you resize so that the outside width dimension is: 17.5 mm in one direction and 23.6 mm in the other (the square part, not connectors with the holes) it should work great.

I sliced this thing using Slic3r - and used default supports. It's probably not the only way to do it, but for my printer it prints vertically with the 'blades' of the dual connector in a vertical alignment.

It printed ok, but the edges of the 'blades' did slightly grind with the cooling fan shroud on occasion. It might be best to use a wide spatula or similar tool to keep the edges flattened, so it won't get too out of shape. Good luck. Once you pop them off the base, They worked quite nicely. See my photos for a nice example of how I used this thing.

description.text:
This is a small part to avoid the filament to break between the extruder and the spool.

The hole is 6mm diameter inclined of 4degrees. Up to now, it's working for me.

26.07.2015
FYI - I have consumed half of my plastic spool without breaking my filament. An interesting point that I have observed is that the filament guide will translate closer and closer to the plastic spool as the filament is consumed. You have to let it translate it or the filament will break. I have uploaded a picture about that.

author: Noelsh

description.text:
My updated version of a case for a slimmed down version of the popular GT2B transmitter.
Some of the updates are:

  • Original screws to hold the case together (now you only need to supply 2 x 3m screws + nuts for the pcb and potentiometer)
  • Using existing powerswitch with a printed extension
  • Can accommodate the included 800mah battery
  • Hole for the bind button
  • A few mm slimmer then v1 and with lots rounded edges

Here's a great tutorial with lots of pictures:
https://endless-sphere.com/forums/viewtopic.php?f=35&t=71922

To assemble you'll need;
2 x 680 ohm resistors (solder where on the inputs to the unused channel)
1 x M3 14mm screw (to hold trigger)
1 x M3 4mm screw (PCB)
2 x M3 nuts

You need to cut off the red areas indicated in the third photo, also cut the bind button as short as possible. The usb-jack needs to be desoldered, add 2 wires (about 10cm) for 5v and ground between the pcb and jack for charging the lipo.
The lipo-battery that comes with the transmitter is about 50% rubber, so peeling back the label and removing the rubber pieces on either side makes it a lot slimmer so you can hot glue it to one side of the case. Don't forget to add electrical/gaffers tape around the battery as not to short it with the pcb.

When you're done do a transmitter calibration on your ESC.

title: curtain stop for asymetrical T-slot slides 15mm wide

description.text:
Today doing soem housekeeping a stop got lost.
Because of strong demand by my wife I'v developped and printed
a spreading peg style curtain stop.
It applies to 15mm wide rails mounted on the ceiling.

Making the print a tight fit is good enough to stop normal moving curtains.
If you have some kids ripping down the stores you may need stronger grip. There is a hole 2mm wide. Push a pin i.e. a tooth pick 2 mm wide toward the top, cut the slim tip first. This spreads the clamps and improves the grip.

Last picture: steps from the idea to the design ;-)

Recommend using ABS this time.
Have printed this thing using 20 percent infill only.
It's ok using PLA as well. Compared with using soft ABS this requires you matching the contour of the railopening more exactly.

title: Sun Goddess Set - Clutch, Ring and Amulet

description.text:
The sun's burning bright, exams are over, and you're in a brilliant mood. The urge to grab some ice cream is overpowering so you decide to run to the nearest stand. But you're wearing your tiniest shorts or skirt and there's nowhere to put your coins and phone! Every girl should have a sturdy clutch large enough to stash her essentials in for quick errands. Accessories to match are awesome too.

Assembly of the clutch should be very easy: the "closer" piece should be glued into place once the barrel hinges have slid into their respective holes to prevent it coming apart. The two parts of the knob will also have to be glued/fitted together.

The ring and amulet are ready to be finished and worn right off the print bed (a string/chain/cord will naturally be necessary for the latter).

Please don't print the clutch yet - I'm still working on the hinge.
The ring and amulet can both be printed at 10% infill and 0.2 layer height.

Updated the part - added vent holes and changed display mounting plate.

A widget for plugging into USB chargers, when they are not charging your phone.

It is electronics project built using ESP8266 and OLED screen. Electronics is under 8 bucks, but the frustration of soldering wires on pins you can barely see is priceless.

This widget has a tilt switch to change from landscape to portrait mode. The source code is available here: https://github.com/ardyesp/WeatherDisplay

It connects to your home WiFi network and periodically requests current and forecast weather from http://openweathermap.org

It is a work in progress.

My test piece is printed in PLA.

Add platform support for printing USB plug and display mounting plate.

Mine is ESP-07, ESP-12 will also work (http://www.adafruit.com/products/2491). 128x64 OLED display based on SSD1306 and is 27mm x 27mm PCB with screw holes at 24mm X 23.5mm.
comments.author: bball61

comments.text: Just reporting on my attempt to send the STL straight to shapeways. It printed fine in white, strong, and flexible, but the dimensions are a bit off. I have two 128x64 OLEDs from Adafruit, the 1.3" linked above, and the 0.96" (https://www.adafruit.com/products/326). Neither quite fits the screw posts in the STL. The piece I printed from STL seems to have center-to-center screw post dimensions 0.95" x 0.925", or about 24mm x 23.5mm. The USB plug seems to be the right size, so I don't think it's an overall dimension scaling issue.
comments.author: willfly

comments.text: I must apologize for linking the wrong OLED display - what I thought was adafruit part, is actually a knockoff bought from online seller. It is smaller in size 27mm square. The one from Adafruit is 35mm, and probably won't fit housing either. I will remove the linked part from earlier comment.

comments.text: Yeah, there are a lot of very similar looking parts floating around. The Adafruit 1.3" one is, I think, 27 mm from inner edge to inner edge of the mounting holes. I noticed Adafruit has recently posted a very similar weather station project including SVG for a laser cut enclosure (https://github.com/andydoro/Huzzah-Weather-Display/blob/master/vector%20files/weather%20station%20vector.svg). I like your flexible USB design better, but the Adafruit SVG may be a good starting point for getting exactly the right dimensions for their parts.

title: Tom's simple PRINTinZ Zebra Plate clip for Printrbot Simple Metal with heated bed
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
If you use adhesive Zebra Plate from PRINTinZ (or their previous pinkish plate like me), these clips are useful to quickly mount the plate to 6mm heated bed – like the original one from Printrbot Simple Metal.

EDIT: New Zebra plate (black&white) is here and it's thicker than the original (pinkish) one. So if you have same (b&w) version, please change model scale before slicing. I will eventually resize original model.
Just print four of them with 100% infill and thin layers (0.2mm or less). Put them to the corners and do not collide with the belt (it is near on the back bottom side of heated bed).

OpenForge
=========
This thing represents the whole sewer set. All released sewer tiles are in the Openforge Sewer Series collection. I'm storing things that apply to the whole set such as painting tutorials here. I will also add each stl from the separate things to this as I release them.

For instructions on how to get started with OpenForge, take a look at our tutorials.

OpenForge is now a patron supported project. I use the resources that my patrons give me in order to get the resources to let me create more sophisticated tiles with a greater level of detail. Please, support me, and I’ll deliver an ongoing stream of awesome gaming terrain. You can find more about OpenForge and Masterwork Tools at our:

  • Online catalog and backer site
  • Website
  • Forums (Mostly we use facebook now)
  • Twitter
  • Facebook

I found that I needed extra cooling on my J-Head mk4 hot end, so I designed this duct to add a 30mm fan to the Mendel90. This part fits inside Wingmaster's square fan duct (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:657540) and tucks neatly under the X-carriage. Simply glue in place and add a fan with four #2 screws.

I've also added a version with two fans, for extra cooling power, but I haven't tried it myself as one seems to be enough. It may interfere with homing in the x-direction - if you try it, let me know.

Print the part however you like, but don't use support as it will fill the duct. Glue into the existing fan duct, and install the fan. You must have a fan duct with a square hole from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:657540, not the default round one.

When I upgraded from M5 Z-screws to 8mm leadscrews I needed a mount for the bearing at the top so I made these.

title: Universal Spool Holder Adapter for Mendel90

description.text:
The spool holder included with Nophead's Mendel90 design (https://github.com/nophead/Mendel90 ) is great if you only have one spool size, but I use many different spools, so I designed this to make the spool holder universal. It uses the same hardware as the existing holder, and mounts in place of the bearings. Any spool with a width of up to 100mm can be placed on the holder with no adjustments.

This works on my Mendel90 spool holder which is 69mm wide. For other widths, you'll need to just scale the roller to a different length.

The extra width means that the mounting hole for the screw that secures the spool holder to the frame doesn't line up, but the holder seems to stay in place just fine using only the hooks on the top of the frame sheet without using the screw at the bottom.

Print four of the mounts and two rollers. The mounts should be printed with support. Attach the mounts to the existing spool holders in place of the bearings, and use the bearings and washers to install the rollers between the mounts. The large M8 washers must be 38mm diameter or smaller.

See photos for more detail.

title: Duplicator i3: Top Mount Spool Adapter

description.text:
This is an adapter to mount filament spools on the top of the printer frame. This is not as good a solution as using a filament guide tube. With my guide tube setup I am limited to around 150mm of print height. If I need more than 150mm I'll use this adapter instead of the guide tube.

Please note I did not design this. It is available for download here:
http://wanhaousa.com/pages/attaching-the-filament-stand-to-the-top-of-the-printer
I added it to thingiverse because it is extremely hard to find on wanhaousa (no links to the page at all).

Printed with PLA @203C with 0.3mm layers @45mm/s. 20% infill and 3 outer shells. 4 layers on top/bottom. I had to slightly enlarge the holes on the steel bracket with a drill bit by hand to fit.
Printed with PLA @203C with 0.3mm layers @45mm/s. 20% infill and 3 outer shells. 4 layers on top/bottom.

author: Drazen

title: Prusa i3 filament reel roller, bracket and guide

description.text:
My Prusa i3 had two metal filament mount arms on the top and the rod for the filament just slotted into two grooves so would fall out if I got the balance wrong with just one reel at one end.

I made up this set of parts to fix this. Firstly, the long brackets fit over the top of the arms and have holes for two lengths of 5mm piano wire. The higher has the end rollers attached (I used a length of black plastic conduit to complete a spool roller) while the lower piano wire has the filament guide, two washers and the roller (made in two parts for ease of printing).

Bearings are 5mm ID, 10mm OD, 4mm thick.

This is all original work, not based on anything out there.

Other parts designed for my Prusa i3 steel upgrade are:

description.text:
This is a replacement for a thing stolen off my car antenna a while ago. This is a work in progress, I may change the width of the wind vanes and add a stop to the top. Basically, this slides along the antenna, from the bottom to the top as your vehicle goes faster.
I made this in 2 parts (the flyer and the flag, so that I can change out flags depending on my mood. :) 5/29/13: Added a sketchup file and included a blank flag part.

I printed these with 3 shells, 10% density, and a raft for each. The pieces are a tight fit with each other, I just tapped them together with a hammer handle and the dovetail holds it in place. I used reflective tape from an auto parts store for the red part of the flag. Have fun with it!

title: Second Wind Trailers - 100% Hand Made Teardrop

description.text:
I created this logo and built my own teardrop trailer, 100% of my own design, no help, just my own engineering sense and determination. The logo was intended to help me create a company with which I can build more trailers for lots of customers. The business end of this venture is the thing that has proven to be more challenging than I initially thought. It's one thing to build a teardrop trailer for yourself - quite another thing to build it for another person. I still have a dream of building that company. Time is not on my side, but perhaps I'll get my 'Second Wind'. Who knows. This trailer is named: Whisper.

More at: http://www.secondwindtrailers.com/

Print using your default settings, and if desired you can switch to a different color about layer 14 or so. I depends on how many layers you slice it to.

Thanks for checking this out!

author: vojtek

title: K8200 - stiffening and herringbone extruder gears

description.text:
My K8200 printer needed some stiffening (screwed two iron bars 8x16mm diagonal to xz and yz) and new bearings. As the progress in print quality was so amazing I decided to also exchange the worn out extruder gears by printed ones. Didn't find the original 10/43 ratio in superior herringbone design here in the forum. So I digged out my library design Gear cutting with free profile shift and designed it quickly from scratch.

  • modulus is 1.5
  • Z10 has 5 mm axes and uses M3 screw and nut. Geared height is 8mm. Full height 19mm.
  • Z43 fits to M8 screw head. Geared height is 7.5mm
  • Axes distance is 40mm

Printed the pair. It came out very well with .2mm layers on the stiffened machine. As lub I recommend silicon grease.

comments.text:
So this gear as the same ratio as the original gear ?
It doesn't require to update the firmware ?
comments.author: 3dCouverte

comments.text: Just count your teeth! A firmware update is required if the ratio is different.
comments.author: 3dCouverte

This remote control is for making three motors go forward and reverse. It was designed as a remote for an ROV, underwater robot. There are three double push double throw switches on this clicker. More photos: http://www.flickr.com/photos/connors934/sets/72157626820192133/with/5825369702/

You laser cut the base and the switches with the spacers in acrylic. Add a strip of conductor such as copper backed adhesive, or something similar along each side of the switch, careful not to connect the side poles. 
Add machine screws to the two outer holes on each end of the switch on the base plate. Cross the opposite corners with a wire. Attach a wire that will go to the motor to each of the terminal screws on one end of the switch.
Power goes to the center two screws. 
When you push down on the switch, it will make the motor go in one direction. Push down on the other side of the switch, and the motor will go in the reverse direction.

author: psbox

title: LED Strip Mount for Quick Connector

description.text:
LED Strip Mount for use with LED connector adapter

This housing prevents movement between the LED segment and the connector.

I left the track mount as it was on the bottom of thing 106844. The track may add other uses although I didn't need it. Clips from other derivatives of the same part should fit this track too.

I shortened the track by 1/3 to fit one segment of 3 LED's and added a bracket on the end so the quick connector was supported.

The connectors I use are here: http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/B00GTGLCXI/donscollecti

Roll of RED LED's http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/B00EKEODA0/donscollecti
